data.title: UTC football: A look at each of the 31 signees for 2024
data.meta_description: UTC coach Rusty Wright and his staff did the heavy lifting on their 2024 signing class in December, then added the finishing touches Wednesday.
data.text:
Wednesday marked the start of a second signing period for college football programs in the 2024 recruiting cycle, though most were far more active in December's early period.

That included the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga, which added just two players Wednesday to bring its total haul for the current signing cycle to 31.

(READ MORE: UTCâ€™s Rusty Wright likes potential of latest football recruiting haul)

Here's a closer look at the Mocs' signees, including both college transfers and high school recruits:

OL Watts Alexander (6-4, 270), Mountain Brook, Ala.

One of two February signees, Alexander was a first-team all-state selection who helped the Spartans to 33 wins over his final three seasons and a Class 6A state runner-up finish in 2023.

DE Joseph Bakhole (6-3, 240), Charlotte, N.C.

The Lousiana-Monroe transfer and midyear enrollee was ranked the eighth-best defensive linemen transfer, according to The Portal Report, after playing in nine games for the Warhawks in 2023.

WR Taylor Crumedy (5-9, 155), Cortelyou, Ala.

The speedster averaged 22.1 yards per catch in his final prep season, named to theClass 1A all-state first team while helping the Bears capture consecutive state championships.

LB Amanuel Dickson (5-11, 200), Greeneville

The midyear enrollee was a two-time Class 4A all-state selection and the Region 1-4A defensive player of the year for the Greene Devils, amassing 442 tackles over his final three seasons.

WR Chris Domercant (6-2, 180), Bellingham, Mass.

The January addition had two highly productive seasons at another Football Championship Subdivision program, Stonehill, with 85 catches for 1,520 yards and 16 touchdowns. He redshirted in 2022, giving him two seasons of eligibility remaining as he begins his UTC career.

RB Justus Durant (5-9, 180), Palm Bay, Fla.

The Shorter transfer had 1,369 rushing yards and 13 touchdowns in 21 career games, getting named to the All-Gulf South Conference first team for the NCAA Division II program. He had five 100-yard games, including a 202-yard showing against North Greenville.

TE Nathaniel Eberly-Rodriguez (6-5, 240), Petoskey, Mich.

A transfer from Division II's Wayne State, he enrolled in January with two seasons of eligibility remaining and six starts and 16 games played under his belt. He averaged 17.8 yards on 12 receptions with a touchdown in his career.

LB Landon Feggins (6-0, 215), Athens

From nearby McMinn County, the 2023 Region 4-5A defensive player of the year finished his prep career with 387 tackles, going over the 100-tackle mark three times. He also had four interceptions, two forced fumbles and two fumble recoveries.

DL Gabe Flores (6-2, 240), Cincinnati, Ohio

A midyear enrollee, Flores was an All-Greater Miami Conference first-team pick in 2023 who had 45 tackles, 4.5 for loss and three sacks in his final season. The Firebirds won two GMC championships during his time.

TE Daniel Green (6-5, 235), Jackson

The two-time Division II-A All-West Region performer at Jackson Christian had 426 yards on 32 receptions in his senior season, and he totaled 11 career touchdowns. The Eagles qualified for the playoffs all four seasons Green was in high school, including a semifinal appearance in 2022.

DE Leroy Harris III (6-5, 215), Brentwood

A three-star prospect, according to 247Sports.com, Harris had 110 tackles in his career along with six interceptions and nine pass breakups for Christ Presbyterian Academy. He was also a part of CPA's 4x100 meter relay team that won the Division II-AA state championship in 2022.

DL Isaiah Harvey (6-0, 240), Warner Robins, Ga.

The 2022 graduate had 66 tackles as a senior for Northside and earned second-team all-region and All-Middle Georgia honors after his junior year.

OL Tracy Jackson (6-4, 305), Memphis

The 2023 Class 6A all-state selection at Whitehaven was ranked the 29th-best interior offensive lineman by On3.com. He chose the Mocs over at least 10 other offers, including Memphis and Missouri.

P Heath Jehu (6-1, 169), Birmingham, Ala.

The Kentucky transfer redshirted in his lone season at the Southeastern Conference program after a senior year at John Carroll Catholic in which he didn't allow a return in 50 kicks his final year, earning all-conference and all-district honors while being named the special teams player of the year in 2022.

K Alen Karajic (6-4, 200), Chattanooga

The East Hamilton alum and Jacksonville State transfer started all four seasons for the Gamecocks, going 152-for-156 on PATs and 48-for-67 on field-goal attempts with a long of 46 yards on four occasions.

K Gray Kelley (6-1, 185), Acworth, Ga.

The brother of current UTC kicker Jude Kelley, Gray was ranked the 17th-best kicker in the country and the No. 1 kicker in the state of Georgia. The former Allatoona standout was 23-of-30 on field-goal attempts in his prep career with a long of 47 and had 16 touchbacks on 25 kickoffs.

RB Eagan Lehman (5-10, 175), Baldwinsville, N.Y.

The midyear enrollee played a prep season at Milford Academy after a productive career at Baldwinsville.

OL Devin Lively (6-3, 275), Lebanon

Lively played a prep season at Air Force Prep after his high school career at Friendship Christian, where he was all-state on both offense and defense as a senior and played soccer and wrestled.

LB Noah Livingston (6-3, 241), Queensbridge, N.Y.

Livingston played two seasons at Division II program Virginia Union, helping the Panthers to a 19-4 record in two seasons with two playoff appearances. He had 12 tackles and a pair of quarterback hurries in 2023.

TE John McIntyre (6-4, 230), Athens, Ala.

McIntyre was an all-purpose player at Athens High School, with 1,193 total yards in high senior season (667 rushing, 503 receiving and 23 on returns) and totaled 19 touchdowns. He also had 138 tackles (20 for loss), seven sacks, 11 quarterback hurries and nine pass breakups while playing defense his sophomore and junior years.

DB Beni Mwamba (6-1, 190), Erlanger, Ky.

Mwamba was an All-Northern Kentucky second-team selection as a senior, when he had four interceptions and nine pass breakups. He broke up 30 passes in his final 23 high school games.

LS Ethan Myers (6-0, 211), Murfreesboro

The Austin Peay transfer was an all-conference pick each of his two seasons with the Governors while also scoring on a 2-point conversion during his career for the United Athletic Conference champions.

OL Nick Paul (6-3, 295), Decatur, Ga.

Paul was a two-time all-region selection at Clarke Central, starting the final 21 games of his career at tackle for the Gladiators.

OL B.J. Ragland (6-2, 279), Chattanooga

The former Red Bank Lions standout and Charlotte transfer played in 10 games with one start on the defensive line for the 49ers, but he is transitioning to the offensive line at UTC. He was a two-time Class 3A all-state selection for the Lions.

DB Taylor Smallwood (6-2, 198), Lawrenceville, Ga.

The Lafayette transfer played in 23 games and accumulated 43 tackles and broke up six passes with a pair of interceptions in his career. He had five tackles and an interception in the Leopards's FCS playoff loss to Delaware.

DB Amaari Smith (5-11, 173), Pahokee, Fla.

The Western Kentucky transfer spent two seasons with the Hilltoppers, playing in one game during his time.

DL C.J. Smith (6-2, 260), Knoxville

The three-star prospect, according to 247Sports.com, had 12.5 sacks as a West High School senior and was a two-time all-state selection. His father Chavis played offensive line for Tennessee from 2000-03.

DB T.J. Springer (6-1, 192), Nashville

Another Western Kentucky transfer, Springer played in 26 games and had 17 tackles, an interception and a pass breakup during his career. He played in bowl games all five seasons he was with the Hilltoppers.

EDGE David Stewart (6-1, 217), Germantown

Stewart spent one season at UT Martin and redshirted after a solid prep career at Germantown.

WR Josh Williams (6-0, 175), Anderson, S.C.

A three-star prospect, according to 247Sports.com, Williams exploded his senior year for Westside, which won the Class 4A state championship. He had 1,738 all-purpose yards (1,362 receiving) and totaled 21 touchdowns his final year, earning all-state recognition.

RB Journey Wyche (5-10, 180) Louisville, Ky.

Wyche recorded 1,700 yards from scrimmage his final season at Ballard, with 26 touchdowns leading the team to the Class 6A state semifinals.
